author: pipermerriam
content:
Ooh, this might be the perfect place for my favorite group decision making approach:

1. Pick someone from "the group" at random
2. That person picks whomever they wish to be the one who makes the decision.

author: potuz
content: I literally use that system for my weekly seminar. But then everyone is on the same footing. Here I foresee a battle to decide who belongs in that group with many people resigning from the EF :) where's that picture from <@301186049323958275> that describes governance ðŸ˜‚

author: pipermerriam
content: Yeah, our ill-defined "group" makes it hard to apply fun mechanics like this.

author: jgm
content:
EL hard forks are devcon locations, CL hard forks are star names.  I don't see any reason for this to change, and we aren't going to have synchronized hard forks anyway (at least this time around).

Seems to me that we're over-complicating the whole thing.  The merge is an event that happens after both layers have been upgraded, and that's what most non-devs will care about.  The hard forks are just pieces of infrastructure that are being upgraded to allow the merge to take place, so not sure that attempting to add significance to their names is a worthwhile effort.

author: potuz
content: Oh no need to argue, I'm sure most will agree (including me) that any name, or even no name, is fine, as long as it happens
